abstract.p: Gómez-Moriana applies contemporary literary theory to classical texts of the Spanish Golden Age, including Lazirillo de Tormes, Don Quijote, Tirso de Molina’s Don Juan play, and Columbus’s Diary. “Gómez-Moriana’s skillful handling of literary theory is matched by his thorough scholarship and excellent knowledge of history.” --Nicholas Spadaccini

abstract.p: During the years of Franco’s dictatorship, an anecdote circulated in Spain that to mind both the intellectual training and the working methods of the Spanish Civil Guard. The post commander of a city receives this telegram from provincial authorities: “Impending seismic activity—epicenter in your town-take appropriate measures.” Three days later—after having had his men work unremittingly, we suppose—the post commander answers his chief’s communiqué, also telegram: “Seismic activity quelled—Epicenter and his men arrested.”

abstract.p: The inclusion of autobiography in the narrative genre is not as evident as it may seem. abstract.p: In Spanish historiography the year 1492 is doubly symbolic, for it coincides not only with the crowning of a long process of national unification, but also with the beginning of Spain’s territorial expansion on a global scale. National unification was consummated with the armed conquest of the last Islamic bastion in Iberian lands, the kingdom of Granada, and the expulsion by decree of the Jews.
